subject: The smartest investors at Vanguard
body:
CONFIDENTIAL BRIEFING PREPARED FOR IMMEDIATE RELEASE





We love giving our InvestorPlace.com members benefits like access to this timely message.
In order to ensure you keep receiving special alerts and offers like this one, please take a moment to click on any of the links in this message to reconfirm that this is the email address where you want to receive emails from InvestorPlace.com 
 






A publication of Fund Family Shareholder Association. This publication, FFSA, and The Independent 
        Adviser for Vanguard Investors are completely independent of The Vanguard Group, Inc.
How the Smartest Vanguard 
        Investors Turn a 25¢ Investment 
        into $89 On a Daily Basis 
SUMMARY:

 Vanguard’s average investor tripled his or her portfolio value over the last 15 years.
But a group of risk-averse Vanguard investors grew their portfolios
eight times larger in the same time period.
Any Vanguard investor can capture 136% greater profits.
Vanguard’s most popular funds doom millions of investors to mediocrity.
Vanguard does not promote its best funds.
19 secrets (revealed in this briefing) hold the key to bigger profits with smaller risks.

If you are holding any of Vanguard’s most popular funds, 
        you could be doomed to mediocrity, or worse, this year.
 Cut Your Risks and Still Make 136% More 
        Money Than the Average Vanguard Investor 
The average Vanguard investor has
          more than tripled his or her personal pot of gold since 1991. A portfolio starting with $100,000 is now worth $384,095. That’s the average.
          And many might say that’s a darn good reason to invest with Vanguard.
But during that exact same time, investors who took my advice on Vanguard saw their personal pots of gold grow not three but EIGHT TIMES
            LARGER.
My name is Dan Wiener and some say I have the Midas Touch when it comes to Vanguard’s funds. Seems every fund I recommend surges beyond
        expectations. Lucky? Not really. I’ve been picking the perfect Vanguard funds for nearly 20 years and I’m doing it again right now!


“Your Vanguard profits will surge 136% beyond your expectations this year.”





Dan Wiener, the man with the Midas Touch for Vanguard funds,
                    wants you to get rich, too.


This is not a prediction. 
              IT’S A PROMISE!
But if you’re holding Vanguard’s most popular funds, your profit surge won’t happen. This Briefing tells you why you’re
              better off selling those funds today, and how this year, you can more than double your profits with a fraction of the risk you’re taking
              now.


It might seem I’m bragging a bit. But I’m just giving the facts. The same $100,000 that the average Vanguard investor grew to $384,095
        pales compared to the $905,530 that investors who followed my advice would have.
We (my subscribers and I) did it all with Vanguard funds. Yes, a profit of $805,530. That’s $521,435 more profit than Vanguard’s
        average investor. Staggering. And sad, because the facts show that the average Vanguard investor, and you might be among them, is missing out on
        $32,589.69 each year in profits. 
Every year you stay with Vanguard’s most popular funds is costing you plenty, my friend. But I’m not writing to you today to tell
        a sad tale. 
I’m going to lift your Vanguard profits dramatically. And at the same time, I’m going to cut your risks, slash your unnecessary investment
        costs and tell you how to get more out of your Vanguard funds. 
How? Well, I’m about to reveal 19 Vanguard secrets that will put you on the right path. But first, let me get some necessary business out
        of the way. 
Turn 25¢ into $89 on a Daily Basis!
That extra $32,589.69 Vanguard profit I deliver each year (about $89 a day in extra profits) to members can be yours for about 25¢ a
        day. That’s the cost of my investment advisory service.
Think of what this could mean to you. When every 25¢ you spend turns into $89—day after day, year after year—your life changes. 


How Dan’s Vanguard 
            Midas Touch 
            Has Made His 
            Subscribers Rich

% Advantage: 136%
              Extra Profit: $521,435


Instead of taking two-week vacations once a year, you can buy a second home in your favorite part of the world, and still afford to jet away to
        other spots whenever you want. 
Instead of taking a part-time job to pay for a comfortable retirement, you can buy or start your own business. 
Instead of selling your home and moving into a smaller, cheaper place, you can amass a fortune, live like royalty and still leave a healthy legacy
        to your children and grandchildren.
To achieve this, all you do is make that 25¢-for-$89 trade-off. And if you do it today, I will welcome you to the “club” with
        11 FREE gifts to get you started. 
If you’re not willing to trade a quarter for $89, I wish you all the luck in world investing with Vanguard on your own. Click
      here now to learn more.
The New Rules for Building a 
        Bigger Fortune with Vanguard
First off: Forget conventional wisdom. It can get you into deep trouble when you’re investing with Vanguard. 
If you want bigger Vanguard profits, you do NOT have to take on bigger risks. But Vanguard really doesn’t want you to know this. 
They want you to keep pouring money into their most popular funds, which brings us to the second rule of Vanguard investing: Forget indexing. 



Fame Is Not Fortune 


Vanguard became famous for indexing, but index investors do not become as rich as my members do. What’s worse is index investors have no
        idea how risky those funds can be. And risk is the enemy. Controlling risks is probably one of the top reasons you’re investing in mutual
        funds. But what you are about to discover will shock you. 
As I reveal 19 secrets critical to your Vanguard success, you will begin to see how my Midas Touch works. And you will see how Vanguard’s
        most cautious investors can be the ones taking on the most risks. Find out what they are by clicking here.
19 Secrets You Must Know Now to
        Build Wealth Safely at Vanguard
Since I do not know what kind of investor you are, the following secrets I’m about to expose cover the entire landscape: Indexing, growth
        investing, Vanguard’s closed funds, sector investing, income investing, annuities, diversification, and secrets covering buying and selling
        Vanguard funds.
VANGUARD SECRET #1
500 Index is not the safest index fund, nor is it the most best-performing index fund, nor is it the best way to invest in
          large-cap stocks. In fact, during the last bear market investors lost more than $40 billion in this fund.
500 Index has more risk built into it than Vanguard wants you to know about. Diversified? Risk free? Below-average risk? Think again, my friend.



Caution: Hidden Risks 


A whopping 26% of the fund’s assets are tied up in just 10 stocks, and nearly half (49%) of its assets are invested in just three sectors.
        What’s more, 500 Index took an eternity—six years—to recover from the tech implosion. In fact, investors just barely got back
        to even in December of 2006. 
VANGUARD SECRET #2
Vanguard has a fund that’s remarkably close to the 500 Index, except it’s safer, performs better, and it’s
          actively managed!
If you want to invest along with the S&P 500, fine. But you’ll be much better off when you do it with a fund that can weed out the dogs
        that live in index funds. 
Vanguard has such a fund, and members of the Fund Family Shareholder Association (or FFSA, the organization I created in 1990 to help investors
        get richer, faster in their mutual funds) know all about it. This fund holds just 120 stocks. 65% of its assets are in stocks that are included
        in 500 Index (the best of the 500). The other 35% of its assets are put to work in other areas. And that’s where this fund’s professional
        management skills prove their worth.
VANGUARD SECRET #3
Index funds, even the best ones, simply don’t compare favorably to Vanguard’s best actively managed funds.
Vanguard has a slew of index funds with growth objectives, the 500 Index among them. And if you’re looking for capital appreciation and
        you’re indexing to get it, well you’re making a costly mistake, one that traps the average Vanguard investor time and time again and
        costs them up to 40% in profits year after year.
Please don’t lose 40% of your profits this year. Join FFSA today. Do not wait for Vanguard to tell you that indexing is last century’s
        way to profit safely. They will never reveal this fact to you.
Indexing is failing now. From 2000 to 2005, Vanguard’s index funds were down a collective 13.3%. But during that same five-year time frame,
        the funds I recommended to FFSA members were up 17.9%—with 13% less risk!



$50,000 Grows To $40,000 


Had you been with us as a member since I created our exclusive Growth Model Portfolio (one of four portfolios I construct exclusively for members),
        a $50,000 investment on your part would now be worth over $400,000. That’s an average annual return of 14.8%—for 16 years.
VANGUARD SECRET #4
Most growth investors buying managed funds are too heavily invested in U.S. stocks.
The real action these days is outside the U.S. Sure, our economy is growing, but our growth rate (expect a slower growth rate this year) is nothing
        like what’s happening overseas. And Vanguard is right there, ready to let you in on all the action. 



Hottest Fund 


After posting gains of 44.5% in 2003 and 20.1% in 2004, Vanguard closed their only truly global stock fund. But in August of 2005, it re-opened
        and kept a standard low minimum ($3,000) to get in. What’s more, and this may shock you, this actively-managed global fund has about half the
        risk of 500 Index. 
Once you become a member of FFSA and start receiving our private advisory, you’ll see that this fund plays a major role in our Growth Model
        portfolio. 
As I said, this global fund is now open once again to new investors. But who knows? It could slam its doors shut again without notice at any moment.
        So please, join us today.
Speaking of closed funds. If you follow Vanguard at all, no doubt you’ve been frustrated to find that many of the best funds are closed. 
Take, for example, the 10-year returns enjoyed by owners of Health Care: +355.5%. Or Capital Opportunity: +324.6%. Funds like these can set you
        up for life! In fact, both of these funds paid my kids’ college tuitions. But both of them are now closed to new investors.
In all, seven of Vanguard’s funds are closed. And many of them are funds you’d be smart to own. No secret there. The big family secret
        is that even if you don’t own them now, you can still get in!
VANGUARD SECRET #5
Vanguard has a form you can pick off their website that enables you to get into their closed funds. 
FFSA members know this secret, of course. And knowing it has enabled many of them to reap tremendous rewards that otherwise would have been shut
        off to them. By joining us, you can unlock many doors that are now closed to you. 
VANGUARD SECRET #6
Vanguard’s closed funds have clones that often present even better investment opportunities.
Capital Opportunity’s kissing cousin is PRIMECAP, which sorry to say, is also closed. But PRIMECAP Core is wide open. It’s a healthy
        hybrid of the two. Less than two years old, PRIMECAP Core is already piling up the profits like crazy (up more than 12% in each of its first two
        years). 



Better Than The Closed Funds 


What about Health Care? Does it have a clone? Yes! But many investors (non-members of FFSA, that is) fall into a trap seeking a Health Care clone.
        The unknowing assume that Vanguard’s Health Care Index Fund is a good alternative. But it is not!
First off, Health Care Index has a minimum initial investment of $100,000. With such a steep entry fee, it’s all but closed to most investors
        anyway. Second, it both underperforms Vanguard’s managed Health Care fund and has a higher risk as well. Not a good combo.
VANGUARD SECRET #7
The manager of Vanguard’s Health Care fund, Ed Owens, runs a health care fund outside of Vanguard that’s wide
          open to you!
Same fund manager. Same fund objectives. Different fund family. The fact that the best alternative to Vanguard’s closed Health Care fund
        is not a Vanguard fund doesn’t stop me from recommending it to FFSA members, especially when there’s no stopping the demands for health
        care.
More than 25% of our 300 million population (78 million of us!) are just now entering the phase of their lives when health care becomes the most
        important aspect of their lives.



Best Investment Trend 


If you can only invest in one trend, health care should be it! And if you can’t get into Vanguard’s Health Care, don’t worry.
        I’ll tell you all about Ed Owens’ other managed health care fund (you can bet the ranch Vanguard won’t tell you about it) as
        soon as you join FFSA.
Another way to capture the growth of America’s 78-million strong baby boom generation is to buy shares of ETFs that are comparable to the
        Health Care fund. You’ll learn which ETF to buy when your FFSA Welcome Package arrives.


“Thanks”
“Your membership price has already returned an improved performance. Thanks!”
—R.W., Kernersville, NC
“...a lot more money...”
 “It’s a comfort to have a talented adviser helping me make fund picks. I’ve come to trust Dan
              and, so far, feel he has made a lot more money for me than I could have on my own.”
—R.S., West Dover, VT
“My future is 
              brighter now”
“I used to only buy Vanguard’s most popular funds. I always went with the biggest, looking for safety.
              But now, with Dan Wiener’s help, I’m seeing much better returns from funds I never considered before. My future is brighter now,
              thanks to Dan.”
—C.H., Boston, MA
“I’ve been a Vanguard 
              investor 
            for years, but...
“I was so wrapped up in trading stocks on my online account that I just about lost sight of Vanguard. When
              it came to time pay my daughter’s college tuition, I saw that my Vanguard funds were making more money than I was trading stocks on
              my own—and I trade with advice offered by several stock-picking gurus! As luck would have it, I received an invitation to join FFSA
              on the same day I checked my Vanguard funds. FFSA promised me even greater Vanguard profits, so I joined. And FFSA kept every promise, big
              time! Now my Vanguard investments are doing even better than before. I know now that Vanguard is where every nickel of serious money belongs—especially
              now that I have FFSA guiding me to the best Vanguard has to offer.”
—W.H., Philadelphia, PA


VANGUARD SECRET #8
Only two of Vanguard’s ten $100,000 minimum sector funds produced double-digit returns. One actually lost money.
If you had $25,000 to pony up and ice water galloping through your veins, you could have gotten into Vanguard’s Energy fund and seen big
        payoffs over the last several years. 
A smaller, albeit still chunky initial investment of $10,000, would have given you entry to Vanguard Precious Metals & Mining. It paid off
        even better than the $25,000 minimum Energy.
While it’s not quite true that the higher the minimum initial investment the lower the returns, it’s pretty darn close to being true. 
The only sector fund that requires the standard $3,000 initial investment, REIT Index, outperformed 80% of the highest-priced funds. 
REIT Index is all about real estate. And you know what’s been happening in that sector lately. It’s cooling fast. So be careful chasing
        after profits here.



Special Caution 


Caution should also be exercised before you go chasing after Energy and Precious Metals. Those two sector funds have been Vanguard’s biggest
        profit generators lately. But what goes up must come down. And the volatility of these two sector funds is so fierce that they represent not investments
        but speculation.
VANGUARD SECRET #9
Buy a high-flying sector fund at the wrong time and you can see two-thirds of your money disappear.
Sector funds are tempting. But buying a sector fund is actually a form of market timing, which individual investors never seem to master. But
        when you’re a member of FFSA, you suddenly have the world’s best portfolio managers, and my track record of success, on your side.
        I make sure of it!
Without an expert guiding you, sector fund investing can be more akin to speculating, which is a nice word for gambling. If you want to speculate,
        be ready to say goodbye to a large chunk of your money. And if you’re ready to lose a bundle speculating, why not skip mutual funds altogether,
        buy a few penny stocks and hope for the best? 
But if you want to be smart and limit your risks, make long-term investments that make real money for you safely and on a consistent basis, join
        FFSA. As a member, you’ll have complete access to the Growth Model portfolio I’ve put together for FFSA members. Join today. 



Best Way To Cut Risk 


As you’ll see when your FFSA Membership Package arrives, you don’t have to throw caution to the wind to grab the big paydays. Some
        of the least-risky funds are some of the best producing!
One more thing. As I’ve mentioned above, many of Vanguard’s sector funds carry a high entry price, calling for a minimum investment
        of $100,000. And most of those just aren’t worth the price of admission. Find out what stocks those are by clicking here.
VANGUARD SECRET #10
Funds that mandate initial investments of $100,000 can be yours for much less when you buy their equivalent ETFs.
Exchange Traded Funds are hot, which is to say they are highly popular, but not necessarily profitable for the investor who doesn’t know
        how to use them properly. You’ll find out which ones are worth the brokerage commissions in your FFSA Welcome Package.
VANGUARD SECRET #11
You can actually lose money in a “safe” fund designed to generate income.
If you invest with Vanguard for income, you have no room for risk. Yet, many Vanguard income investors have their money in bond funds and Treasuries
        that are more than twice as risky as their benchmark, the Lehman Aggregate Bond Index.
Ok, maybe you don’t expect returns as high as you might get in a growth fund, but you certainly do expect less risk. And you certainly don’t
        expect to lose money. But many Vanguard income investors do lose money. Take inflation into consideration and even more are losing money in income
        funds.
VANGUARD SECRET #12



Beware Of The "Name Game Trap" 


57% of Vanguard’s taxable income funds are riskier than the industry-standard benchmark. Of the family’s tax-exempt
          income funds, 64% are more risky.
But how would you know this? Vanguard doesn’t tell you. When it comes to helping you pick an income fund, Vanguard actually helps you fall
        into traps. 
I call it the “Name Game Trap.” Vanguard has a lot of funds with “income” in their names. But my Income Model portfolio
        constructed for FFSA members includes only one fund that has “income” in its name, and it only constitutes 10% of our model income
        portfolio. 
I’ve examined all of Vanguard’s income funds and found most of them aren’t worth your dollars. In our quest to always double
        the profits of the average Vanguard investor, I’ve found just one that does the job well enough to qualify for my portfolios—and you
        can get its name when you join FFSA. Click here now. 


Get Into Vanguard’s 
              Closed Funds

                (7-yrs)


Join FFSA Today!
Learn how you can blast open the gates of Vanguard’s closed funds. And find out about the little-known open funds that work as alternatives.
              In many cases, the alternatives outperform their closed cousins. Click here now. 


VANGUARD SECRET #13
You can safely increase your income with a selection of dividend-paying equity growth funds that are actually less risky than
          most bond funds.
So please, join us and stay out of the traps—get the truth about the many safe ways you can increase your income year after year. Our clear
        strategy for blending equity growth funds to get a higher return is laid out for you when you become a member. 
VANGUARD SECRET #14
One Vanguard annuity has actually performed better than its underlying fund.



Vanguard's #1 Annuity 


Vanguard won’t steer you away from any of their variable annuities, but they should forbid you from buying some of them.
You see, Vanguard’s annuity funds are tax-deferred clones of other funds. Buying one for your 401(k) is a costly mistake. Annuities are
        expensive when compared to the underlying funds they mimic and there is absolutely no reason for you to have an annuity in an account that’s
        already tax advantaged.
Since they are more expensive than their underlying funds, annuity returns are almost always subpar. I said “almost.” 
And it’s not like the underlying fund, Windsor II, is a dog. It has rewarded investors with returns of 61.9% over the last five years. Still,
        the annuity fund did even better—70.7%.
The manager of this annuity is Jim Barrow, one of Vanguard’s all-time best equity fund managers. The underlying fund, Windsor II, is run
        by a host of different managers. But Mr. Barrow runs this annuity all by himself.



A Safe 70.7% Return 


And yet, his is not the overall best Vanguard annuity fund. That title belongs to the tax-deferred clone of PRIMECAP. (Unlike PRIMECAP, this annuity
        fund is not closed to new investors.) 
Your FFSA Welcome Package has all the details on these two top Vanguard annuities, as well as details on all of Vanguard’s best funds. Join
        today.
VANGUARD SECRET #15
MidCap Growth has a remarkably close correlation to SmallCap Growth, which is closely correlated to LargeCap Index.



Another Hidden Risk 


No matter which type of fund fits your investment objectives the best, you’re looking for the safety of diversification. That’s why
        you turn to mutual funds, isn’t it?
Bet you didn’t realize that 13 of Vanguard’s growth funds have the exact same top-10 holdings. So, if you own two growth funds, chances
        are you’re overexposed on those stocks. Overlapping investments, which is the opposite of diversification, is a trap far too many Vanguard
        investors fall into. 
In 2005, Vanguard introduced Diversified Equity, to help investors achieve favorable diversification easily. It’s a fund made up of other
        funds.
The core of the fund is Growth & Income, which is just about as close as you can get to 500 Index. 
Diversified Equity also includes Windsor and Windsor II, U.S. Growth and Morgan Growth, Capital Value and MidCap Growth. So yes, Vanguard does
        reach a degree of diversification with that mix.



Another "Name Game Trap" 


But still, in the end, Diversified Equity isn’t much better than a straight total-market index fund. You simply don’t get the safety
        you seek from Diversified Equity, no matter what Vanguard’s marketing might say. FFSA members know to avoid this disappointing fund. 
However, the Model Portfolios presented and tracked every month in our private advisory, The Independent Adviser for Vanguard Investors, are putting
        this fund and others to shame on all counts! Diversification and returns! 
VANGUARD SECRET #16
You could get hit hard with taxes on gains the fund achieved during the months before you jump in.


FFSA MEMBERSHIP IS 
            FOR EVERY KIND OF
            VANGUARD INVESTOR 
Each of Dan Wiener’s four model portfolios is a collection of the very best Vanguard funds for a variety of investment strategies
                and preferences. Each issue of Dan’s private advisory, The Independent Adviser for Vanguard Investors, tracks these four model
                portfolios for you:

Growth Model
Conservative Growth Model
Income Model
Growth Index Model



Can you imagine Vanguard telling you not to sink a large amount of money into any taxable fund late in the year? 
Funds normally pay out capital gains at the end of the year. Why should you pay taxes on gains realized before you got on board? So please, do
        not buy just prior to a fund’s distribution date. Wait until the beginning of the year, or at least until after distributions are made. The
        money you’ll save on taxes adds up and goes directly to your bottom line.
VANGUARD SECRET #17
You can save on taxes and penalties by NOT automatically reinvesting your distributions.
Generally, automatically reinvesting capital gains distributions is a fine idea, but this practice can lead to a higher tax bill if you’re
        the kind of investor who rebalances your portfolio from time to time.
Buying more shares of a fund could conflict with rebalancing decisions that say you should be scaling back a bit. This will only lead you to a
        bigger tax bite, since you’d have to sell some of your automatically reinvested shares. And if a back-end load is involved, then you could
        find yourself paying that penalty as well.
What should you do with your capital gains distributions? Have them directly deposited into your money market account. You’ll still pay
        taxes on your distributions, but now you’ve given yourself the flexibility of moving that extra cash into the funds your rebalancing decisions
        say need beefing up.
VANGUARD SECRET #18
Funds that lose money can still hand you a tax bill.
Obviously, paying taxes and taking a loss is a double whammy you do not want. Yet, many mutual fund investors find themselves in that situation
        year after year. Believe me, that’s no way to build wealth for your future.
That’s why it’s so important for you to invest in tax efficient funds. FFSA membership will help you do this. As a member, you learn
        all sorts of ways to make sure nothing comes between you and your profits.
VANGUARD SECRET #19
Vanguard will accept additional investments in any amount, even less than $1.
Vanguard wants you to believe there’s a $100 minimum on investments you make into existing accounts. Not true. There is no such thing as
        a minimum additional investment.



The Holy Grail for Vanguard Investors


Invest as much as you can as often as you can. And during those months you might be a little tight, keep on investing even if you only have a
        few bucks to put toward your future. It pays! And it pays double when you invest armed with the unique intelligence FFSA membership injects in
        you. 
Vanguard is a huge family with more family secrets than can be revealed here. Join FFSA and all the family secrets will be revealed
      to you. 
Knowing all the secrets certainly helps, but the bottom line is making sure your money is in the funds that are best for you. And that’s
        the core advantage of membership.


Each Page of This FREE Gift Gives You 
              More Information Than Vanguard Ever Will!
In
                this comprehensive book you’ll find: 

Complete, detailed profiles of every Vanguard fund (sample page shown in illustration below). 
Dan Wiener’s specific insights on every fund—he tells you to buy, sell, or hold, and why. 
Data on all of Vanguard’s fund managers and outside management companies. 
Year-by-year comparative return charts. 
Fund comparisons by size, risk and portfolio turnover. 
Vanguard’s history, philosophy, services and policies. 
Important Vanguard phone numbers. 
And much, much more!


Fund Objective 
              States the fund’s primary and secondary objectives, types of securities, and percentage cash positions. Tells you if the fund is right
              for you.
Total Return 
              Shows both the cumulative and annualized returns for the fund over the past three, five, seven and 10 years. Tells you how well the fund
                has performed over time.
General Information 
              Lists minimum initial investments, percentage yield, when dividends are paid, the fund’s date of inception, its portfolio manager,
              fees, telephone switch privilege and more. Tells you the basic facts you need to know.
Performance Comparison 
              Compares the yearly returns of the fund to the S&P 500 (monthly, too). Tells you if the fund has fared better or worse than the market
              as a whole.
1996-2006 Performance 
              Shows year-by-year total return, plus income and capital gains distributions, operating expenses, portfolio turnover rate, risk ratings,
                size in $millions, and price at year’s end (Net Asset Value). Tells you if the fund is efficient, profitable, safe and more.
Risk Level 
              Shows the Maximum Cumulative Loss (MCL) during the fund’s history, the number of months it took to accumulate that loss (MTL) and the
              number of months it took to recover (MTR). Tells you the relative risk level of the fund.
This one-of-a-kind guide is yours FREE when you join FFSA!


What Kind of Investor Are You?
Do you favor large-caps? Do you invest for income? Growth? Do you feel most comfortable with index funds?
I won’t pass judgment on your investment comfort zones or objectives. If you’ve just started out investing, if you’ve been at
        it for years, if you’ve reached retirement or will within a few years, that’s your business.
My business is to empower you as a Vanguard investor. I’ll help you reach new levels of investment intelligence, satisfaction and wealth,
        no matter what kind of Vanguard investor you are.
I do this with four model portfolios. Each model portfolio is made up of a collection of the very best Vanguard funds for each of the following
        investment goals:

Long-Term Growth 
Conservative Growth
Income and Growth
Growth through Indexing

Naturally, I want your membership to take off like a rocket and put you on your way to double profits right from the start. That’s why I
        have a box full of gifts in my office with your name on it. May I have your permission to send you these gifts?
The Most Important Gift Of All
The one gift that stands above all the others is The 2007 FFSA Independent Guide to the Vanguard Funds. I’m betting that you have
        never seen anything like it before.
This gift alone gives you more than 225 pages of advice, analysis, facts, and figures on more than 100 Vanguard funds. Each fund is broken down
        so that you fully understand what a fund does, who’s running the show, and most important—why you should or shouldn’t own it.
Each profiled fund gets a full page of in-depth coverage, showing you information—at a glance—you can’t find anywhere else. 
You’ll be amazed at how many fund facts you get and you’ll be amazed at how fast you get them. You learn levels of risk, performance
        over the long and short term, and my own take on the fund, including my personal buy or sell recommendation.
Go to the back of this guide and you’ll find special sections revealing even more important facts in an easy-to-use, easy-to-understand
        format, facts you may never discover on your own (unless you get this book), including:

Top holdings of each fund.
The biggest and smallest funds, ranked by size, and why this matters.
The oldest and newest funds, some of which may deserve your dollars, and some of which don’t.
Funds ranked by risk. Need I say more?
Funds ranked by turnover. A good start when looking for funds that won’t cost you more in taxes than they earn in returns.
Funds ranked by operating expenses.
Funds ranked by performance. 
The place where the investment rubber meets the road.
And an ingenious fund correlations chart that will keep you from overloading on one type of investment rather than diversifying the way the
          most successful investors do. Let me explain.

This correlations chart shows you how closely the performance of one fund tracks that of another. All you need to do is apply a quick glance at
        the chart.
Use this chart to make sure you do not have overlapping investments. Use it to make sure you reach the level of diversification you desire. Use
        it to find alternatives to closed funds. Use it to find alternatives to funds that have out-of-reach minimum initial investment requirements.
You cannot get this book anywhere else. I’ve written it for the exclusive use of FFSA members. 
It’s yours FREE when you join FFSA, and you can keep it FREE even if you cancel your membership immediately.
Same guarantee goes for all the other gifts I’ve reserved in your name. Each gift (there are 11 of them!) is described in more detail below. 
But first, let me tell you about the special offer I’ve put together—it's our best introductory offer ever!
Exclusive Discount Offer Loaded With FREE Gifts!
I can’t afford to make this generous offer to every Vanguard investor. But I will pass it along to another if you don’t want it. In
        addition to the $89 extra profit per day you get as a member, you also get:

Monthly issues of our members-only advisory, The Independent Adviser for Vanguard Investors, including:
          
comprehensive analysis of overall market conditions, 
performance analysis of all four model portfolios,
exclusive interviews with Vanguard fund managers,
fund distribution schedules,
fund manager changes,
advance news of new funds,
warnings of funds facing closure,
alternatives for closed funds,
and yes, even more, much more!


telephone hotline access,
private website access,
access to the FFSA message boards, comprised of some of the savviest Vanguard investors ever found,
discounted dues for the first or first two years of your membership, your choice,
up to 11 free gifts:



BONUS
                GIFT #1:
Indexing for Maximum Profit at Vanguard
              Vanguard is famous for its menu of index funds. But not all index funds are good choices. In fact, only a few are worth your investment dollars.
                And Vanguard’s biggest fund, 500 Index, is not one of them. This bonus gift is the only source that reveals the very best Vanguard
                index funds that belong in your portfolio.


BONUS
                GIFT #2:
Capturing Global Wealth with Vanguard
              Sure, the Dow is at an all-time high. But markets in Europe are also reaching new highs. And then there’s China, the fastest-growing
              economy on earth, growing three to four times faster than our own. Yet U.S. equity funds are still more popular. Break away from the crowd
              and enjoy breakout profits with international stock funds. Vanguard’s menu of international funds is extensive. Which ones are the
              best? Which ones are too risky? Which ones belong in your portfolio? Find out without delay and watch your Vanguard profits soar.


BONUS
                GIFT #3:
Managing Cash Profitably with Vanguard
              How can you make a mistake with a money market fund? Easily, especially when you have so many choices. This gift makes it easy for you to
                avoid the mistakes others unknowingly make with their cash. And your gift gets even more valuable when it explains how to use your cash
                smartly so that you never miss out on opportunities.


BONUS
                GIFT #4:
Conquering Complexities at Vanguard: Making Success
                  Simple
              Vanguard has rules for buying and even more rules for selling funds. Mess up and you could be out a ton of money. And then there are the
              tax rules. Oh my. But none of this is a source of confusion for FFSA members. Get this bonus gift and learn the secrets revealed in your
              statements, discover the best way to organize your statements, how to account for dividends, the yearly portfolio decisions you must make,
              and what you should do at tax time to save yourself a bundle.


BONUS
                GIFT #5:
What to Do Now at Vanguard: Your Top Priorities
              Long-term investing doesn’t mean no action is necessary. Funds change managers and sometimes even objectives. And the economic winds
              are always shifting. That’s why it’s critical to stay in touch with what you own and what you should own. In this bonus gift,
              you’ll learn about the best growth fund for 2007, the best income fund, the best fund if you’re going to retire in the next five
              years, the best index fund for 2007, the safest way to invest in the coming tech rebound, the best place for your cash, and more.


BONUS
                GIFT #6:
The 2007 FFSA Independent Guide to the Vanguard
                  Funds
              No Vanguard investor should be without this resource. It is the bible of Vanguard mutual fund investing. More than 100 of Vanguard’s
              best funds are deeply profiled in quick-reading fashion. You learn more about each fund in just a few minutes than you’ll ever learn
              directly from Vanguard. (See above for a sample page.) This single resource uncovers terrific alternatives to closed funds
              and funds that have prohibitively high initial investment requirements, tells you whether or not you own funds with overlapping investments,
              helps you insure that your portfolio is properly diversified, shows you each fund’s top 10 holdings, warns you of the risk of each
              fund, and gives you Dan Wiener’s buy/sell/hold recommendation on each fund.


BONUS
                GIFT #7:
The Independent Guide to Vanguard ETFs
              Exchanged Traded Funds, indexing investments that trade like stocks, are hot, which is to say they are wildly popular. Vanguard introduced
                its variant in 2001. ETFs can give you terrific tax advantages, can be much cheaper than even the lowest cost mutual fund, and offer you
                greater flexibility to target a specific sector or geographical region. Vanguard’s ETFs are examined under a microscope in this book.
                You’ll learn which ones are right for you, which ones to avoid, which ones serve as ideal alternatives to Vanguard’s closed
                and high-entry price funds, which ones are safest and which ones carry the most risk. You cannot get this under-the-hood analysis anywhere
                else. Join FFSA today and get yours FREE!


BONUS
                GIFT #8:
Magnifying Your Income 2X with Vanguard
              $15 value. Life with twice the income is twice as nice. And this gift shows you how easily you can double your income with Vanguard. And
                make sure that your income keeps increasing year after year! You’ll discover what few Vanguard income investors know, such as the
                bond fund that’s best for 2007, the only annuity fund you should own, the fund that kicks off more income to you than municipal bond
                funds and dividend-based funds. Why live life with less income than Vanguard has to offer you? Your FFSA membership will keep you in the
                money for the rest of your life!


BONUS
                GIFT #9:
Getting Richer Racing to Retirement with Vanguard
              If retirement is in your crosshairs, obviously it’s time to take aim at handsome profits without ugly risks. Not so obvious are the
              funds you should own at this stage of life. Many investors go for target maturity funds or index-based funds. But this is a mistake. Too
              many investors have their portfolios all out of whack, but you won’t be one of them once you get your hands on this book. You’ll
              discover exactly how your portfolio should be constructed so that you get where you want to be in five years or sooner.

                GIFT #10:
Getting High Returns On Top of Big Dividends at

              Dividend-paying stocks are safe, right? Not always, especially when those stocks fall into sectors like energy and real estate. But Vanguard
